commentBody: A little slow going, but I enjoy the "meta" aspect of this one
What a fabulous collaboration! Congratulations to Zachary on this amazing achievement and to his erstwhile collaborator. I enjoyed this one immensely.

[One split down the middle, at times]




MAGIC( )ANSASSISTANT

Sitting in Little Italy waiting for my food.  What a delightful distraction as I sit in the packed house.

So many curveballs that I was able to swat out of the park.

Altered States always reminds me to shy away from those kinds of activities, lol.

I'm always looking for extras: I found "misplaced," but do the correct letters anagram into anything, and are they hidden someplace that I missed?

Loved the movie when it was new, and this puzzle was great too, solved it in 35 without googling anything

Great debut Zachary and a Sunday too!
I was originally a bit lukewarm on this theme but I wish I had looked at the changed letters‚Äîthat really ups the ante in my opinion, because my main objection was that the changed letters could have been anything. That makes an Ok theme into an elite one in my opinion. The theme entries were all smoothly done. I confess I jumped to the revealer when I was stumped by the theme early, and that made it much more fun actually (surprised you knew the movie it‚Äôs well before your time).
I thought the top was pretty easy but I got hung up later on, my own problems. RAVE before FAVE, RH√îNE before RHINE, HBO before ABC, RUTH before OUTS, IRONWEED before IRONWOOD, PRESS before PROSE, NOBAR before NOTIP, I just got bamboozled all over the place. But I like that. I really loved the clue for OOHIMSOCARED, and ‚Äúsoldiers with long arms‚Äù especially with POLEAX elsewhere in the grid. I look forward to seeing more from you, Zachary. (I shouldn‚Äôt leave you out John but this is old hat for you, and I sense a young spirit in most of this puzzle).
My Diary of a Crossword Fiend review: https://crosswordfiend.com/2025/12/13/sunday-december-14-2025/#ny
28A. Sadly, to call the EPA a pollution-fighting organization is no longer accurate.
Congratulations to you, Zach, on an incredibly impressive debut! I look forward to encountering more of your puzzles in the years to come.
Pretty easy Sunday

I really enjoyed this tour through altered states with lots of interesting fill along the way. "Did some school reporting?" was especially fun. Congratulations on a smashing debut, Zachary. You are well on your way to being a legend of Sunday puzzles just like John.

I'm stuck.

The puzzle appears complete and correct.

Should I not use a robust for the swapped letters?

Altered States -- classic puzzle in so many ways.  And classic movie, too. It's nice this puzzle contains SENSORS, since sensory deprivation is a key element in the movie.  And quite a feat, the circled letters in proper order spelling MISPLACED. And for the trifecta coming up with all those unusually flavorful theme answers. Some might find the plethora of proper names a little burdensome, but they're all gettable with the crosses. It holds up.

If soldiers with long arms attack a major coin producer, would they SPEAR MINT? Or would they use a pole axe to FLIP A HOUSE over?

I wonder how many Ohioans have married Oahuans and had children who were thus Oahioans. Questions like this keep me up at night!

On to the GRIDDIES, 2025...

As with my previous posts, please REPLY to this with any nominations for favorite puzzles of 2025 below this message. Name of puzzlemaker(s) and date of puzzle required, short description of puzzle encouraged but optional. So please go back through the archives, refresh your memory of good solves and clever themes, and get back to me! 

This year the puzzle is being run by

Eric Hougland
Me
Marshall Walthew
Loved "Where high schoolers work on their numbers?"!!

An average Sunday puzzle that I finished in my average Sunday time.  I liked the theme but it was sort of beside the point.  You didn‚Äôt need it to solve the puzzle, although once I recognized it did give me some free letters when I could see what state was going to be altered. 

The puzzle put me in mind of the advice I give to crossword neophytes frustrated by tricky clues, rebuses and the like:  Patience you must have, my young PADAWAN.‚Äù

Fun puzzle!

[Editor prior to Will Shortz]

EUGENEMAL(E)SKA

I really enjoyed ALOT of the clues and answers. I thought a good chunk of them were very wittily worded/coded. I was smiling and chuckling to myself damn near the whole time i was solving (just under 30min one of my fastest Sundays!!)
I did get hung up on 30D. With all the weird and dangerous animals Australia is known for, I needed the crossings and still took me a while to suss it out. And I am still shocked that DINGO is their largest carnivore
Since its been mentioned I shall end with the obligatory
"Maybe the dingo at you baby!"

Got to the party a little late due to a dinner engagement, but thought it was quite an interesting theme, and certainly appeared to be a challenge to construct.

Nevertheless, at the end I expected the circled letters to be capalbe of rearranging themselves into other spots to create the correct state names.  I was disabused of that idea when there wasn't an O to make a complete Ohio.

I realize it would have been difficult or even impossible to accomplish this, but it seemed like the puzzle was asking for that final touch.

I enjoyed todays puzzle.  It took me a bit because the first theme clue I thought I had with FLIP HOUSES instead of FLIP A HOUSE.  But once I saw I OWE YOU ONE I figured out the state theme and the rest of them fell into place.

Lots of well worded clues today, only a few nichey proper nouns and all of them with reasonable crossing clues.
I agree with the request that puzzle constructors stop using the clue ‚Äúpollution-fighting org.‚Äù for the EPA. It‚Äôs been just the opposite for almost a year.

First off: Happy 100th birthday Dick Van Dyke! Maybe we will get a Van Dyke themed puzzle. I learned last night that he played two parts in Mary Poppins: Bert and Mr Dawes Sr.

My one comment on today‚Äôs puzzle: shocked that it took me so long to get DENVERMINT. Given I live 22 minutes away from it.

...

Ah, Sunday. Rest easy in the saddle, 'cause there ain't nothing Out West but blue skies and tall grass . . . 

I was fillin' my puzzle on a dusty Way Out West-a road,
When along came a duo with a long and circle-dotted load.
"If you're goin' to win a star, Nell, with us you can ride."
IWANTIN with John and Zack so I settled down inside.
They asked me if I'd seen a grid with both OHlM and MAR S LAND.
I said, "I've been in ALTEREDSTATES before, I ain't no PADAWAN!"

I've solved every way, man.
MISPLACED and I still play, man.
Cussed at grids all day, man.
OHIMSOSCARED (No way, man!)
Gold stars?  I just don't care, man.
I've solved every way.

I've solved with
Whoknows?, Counterflow, Facts? NO!, Missed the quota,
Bluff and go, Dang oreo, Wishiknow, Solvedit-sorta,
Winme? Ha!, Tight craw, Ooh and awa, No diploma,
TAPA?, Pained paws, Need Java, I'minnacoma,
Bluster, Fillnomore, Shut the door, I aint yeller!
Took apilla, Grindmymaxilla, HotTortilla! Imgonna filler!

I've solved everything, man.
Should have a gold prize ring, man.
Crossed these puzzle squares, man.
I SNARLSAT Thursday fare, man.
Dang clues I've SCOPED my share, man.
I've solved everything!
Nice work Zachary and John!   Enjoyed the puzzle (and your Constructor Comments) a lot!!
Fun puzzle! Congratulations to Zachary and John on their first partnership, hopefully the first of many.

Delightful puzzle!  Thanks.

Lots of total unknowns to me‚Ä¶ 23A, 29A, 39A, 40A, 42A, 42D, 51D, 87D.  I got really lucky on 63D, as I used to work with lignum vitae.

But I‚Äôve learned from a year of these comments and the wordplay column to just keep filling and the crosses and deducible answers eventually permit figuring the total unknowns.
You might be more familiar with Altered States as the reference at the end of a-ha's video "Take On Me" where our hero smashes his way into out world in the hallway.

Zachary: congrats on the fantastic debut! And for the gracious Constructor's Note

John: Awesome work as a mentor

Teens with curiosity, wit, initiative, and humility? Experts willing to share their time and expertise with the next generation? There's hope for us all yet!

I'm so impressed that someone so young is a co-creator of this puzzle.  Well done to both writers!

"Altered States" was about the only clue I was certain of.  Still remember how mind-bending that film was.

I thought last night was difficult when I decided it was time to put the duvet cover back on the queen sized comforter and warm things up.  Whoever designed duvet covers must be a close relative to the genius who made the unfoldable fitted bottom bed sheet.  I am 5 ft 4 in. tall now and I weigh 129 lbs., and at 91, flinging myself around the room with these two meant-to-be-together oceans of cloth and cursing the sadist who made them rectangles instead of squares, because when the comforter goes into the cover, they had better be headed in the same direction or I will have to start over wasn't easy.  I crawled inside the thing and pushed, poked, and jabbed the lumpy comforter into the corners, crawled out and gave it all a vicious shaking, and it worked.  We were warm and cozy last night.

I'm happy for everyone who aced this puzzle and found it an easy, fun thing to do.  I didn't find it so easy, and worst of all, I have an error that I cannot find.  I'll find it, but I have to say, I'm beginning to feel my age, and I see that the rest of this really is going to be a challenge.

yet another precocious setter to shoo off my lawn.
just kidding.
mostly.
very good sunday.
please do more.

@Caitlin
You were perplexed by the clue for the only prior appearance of SPEARMEN -- 'opera extras'. You would have found many more references by hunting for SPEAR carriers -- a traditional idiom for minor actors kitted out with spears and used to fill out the stage. The idiom appears in online versions of Merriam Webster (with a clearly wrong date of first use), Cambridge (which cites Hansard),  and Collins Dictionaries.
The moment I saw "Lurk" was the moment I knew we had a teen author. What a great clue

What a stellar debut, Zachary. And John, fantastic mentoring/constructing on your end. You two make a great team. This was really pleasing to solve. Lots of misdirection followed by sweet ahas. I really liked DRUMLINES. If you‚Äôve never seen a drumline competition, it‚Äôs truly amazing to watch. There was a movie about it in the early 2000‚Äôs starring Nick Cannon https://youtu.be/2-7Jdip2Pfw?si=eN6F52RCxF2iajhJ Even more impressive is actual schools competing https://youtu.be/lMRrjliY4z8?si=UI1boTzZ0UpapqDn My final thought is that CURSIVE is becoming a lost art. My oldest son who is now 31 learned it in school. My middle son who is almost 20 was learning it in third grade in Texas, but we moved back to California mid school year and there was no further focus on it that year on. My youngest daughter who is 15 was only taught her signature and is unable to even read cursive. It may as well be a foreign language to her. I have to ‚Äútranslate‚Äù the cards she receives for her birthday and holidays üòÜ My goal is to teach her before she graduates from high school ü§ì

Excellent debut!
No notes.
HOLY CATS! A high-school JUNIOR. What an amazing puzzle!

No, no, no, no, no.

A thousand times no.

I will not tolerate yet *another* constructor who could quite easily be my grandchild, or great grandchild.

It just isn't right that such a terrific puzzle is produced by someone who is decades younger than my crowns.

I won't stand for it any more.
Because I had WRAPSUP instead of WRAPUPS, I fell into a 20-min time vortex üòî
Terrific puzzle from a creative team. Hope to see more from both of you!

I love all the learning opportunities these puzzles provide. For example, today I learned that if you change one letter in a state's name to another, the altered name is gibberish!

Who knew?

Clever clue from the archives which I got right away thanks to last Sunday's puzzle:

Made a little lower? (6 letters)

Notwithstanding the impressive debut and excellent collaboration that generated this puzzle and accepting that I‚Äôll forever be on the solver side of the equation, no one is OAHUAN. 

Once ALTEREDSTATES was in (from crosses) seeking state names that fit accelerated the solving. 

Had the same feeling as others that MISPLACED could‚Äôve done more work but indeed that would be a trick too far. 

Well done to the creators and thanks.

I have never seen or read The Merchant of Venice, so I wasn't familiar with Shylock. Of course I've heard the name, plus "pound of flesh." So wiki to the rescue. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shylock Wow. Really awful plot. Although open for interpretation about what Shakespeare was getting at. Hard to imagine a character winning in the end after defaulting on a loan, refusing to pay, assaulting the lender, and then stealing from him. Plus I just got the pun in Soldiers with long arms being SPEARMEN. Hah. Great puzzle, fun solve.

When the first clue of a puzzle is a Marvel character, followed closely by *anything* from Game of Thrones, my mood sours.  Fortunately the bulk of the remainder was enjoyable, the theme easily sussed, and the clueing good. 
  16 years old. Ugh.

I've done about half of this crossword and, for the first time, I don't  think I'll be able to finish. I didn't get near a theme.

Nothing to do with the construction - just for me, there are so many words I just don't know. Almost none of the proper names, except the river and the composer, and there are a few. It's quite difficult to guess names like PADAWAN, MIKA, NEWELL and YENTE. 

I looked up a few, like Shaquille (supermodel? rapper?) and I could look them all up, but although I understand about learning new things, but I don't know the names of British TV presenters (not interested) so don't think I'll learn the US ones! 

Yesterday was a breeze - but not today. Back tomorrow.

First of all, a big congratulations to you, Zachary, on an excellent debut.  John Kugelman is one of my favorite constructors, and you are a more than worthy collaborator.

[False alarm announcement] for OOH I'M SO SCARED, and [Turns back the clock, maybe?] for REWINDS were two favorites, but the entire puzzle sparkled.

I'm not sure who clued SPEARMEN with [Soldiers with long arms], but that was priceless.

I originally had Hah for [Like hell!] and laughed when I had to change it to HOT.

Lots of unknowns for me today, but all gettable with crosses.
ENOS reminds me of Beppo: From snl: https://youtu.be/fjCX5F74zIM?si=BPiSsenKc2ezh-J1

This puzzle?  A true OR(I)G(I)NAL!




Et tu, emu.
Loved this! A true debeaut.
It's a snowy Sunday morning here in NJ, and this puzzle was a nice accompaniment !

I've already responded to someone else's comment on the puzzle which, as usual, takes the road less traveled. So this is just a Six Degrees of Kevin Bacon story.

My daughter's grandmother lived in a building on the Upper West Side of Manahattan. There was a boy about her age on the same floor that she often would play with when she visited. I had no idea at the beginning that the boy was William Hurt's son. His mother, a ballerina, tried to sue Hurt in New York, seeking recognition of their relationship as a common-law marriage under South Carolina law. The New York court held that the relationship between Hurt and Jennings did not qualify as a common-law marriage under South Carolina law and found in Hurt's favor that no marriage existed. I don't think the poor kid ever had a relationship with his father. After reading more about him, it's no wonder his career kind of tanked.
What a wonderful puzzle. Would love to see this collaborative combo again.

There have been state-based themes before, but I don‚Äôt ever remember seeing this clever one. Props to Zachary, who came up with it, according to the constructor notes.

I love how the process of figuring out the states ‚Äì from the length of the gray squares and from crosses ‚Äì helped get the full theme answer it is embedded in.  There was more pleasure in this than just figuring out the theme answer from simply crosses and clue.

I also love how in some areas this puzzle fought me, checked my INERTIA.  Sometimes it was from tricky cluing, other times from no-knows.  I prefer a Sunday with rub, one that engages, rather than simply a time filler.

Thus, a tip-top outing, entertaining and absorbing.  A lovely activity while GALES are blowing outside.  Thank you both!

I wish this had been a lousy puzzle so I could write "One of the constructors is how old?! No wonder! The editors should CAN TEENS!"

Sadly it wasn't lousy. Maybe tomorrow. Ever the optimist. 


I agree that the EPA clue is, at best, out of touch. What they've done to the agency is a (biohazardous)stain on Nixon's legacy.

Excellent work, especiallyfor such a young constructor.

 I tend to mix up European rivers and therefore spent way too long wondering what a FORETRAP could be. Oops.

Congrats to the constructors.  16!  

However, I seem to be in the minority by thinking this was a sub-par Sunday.  The theme was somewhat interesting but completely unnecessary in the actual solving of the puzzle.  Cluing of the theme entries was just way too straightforward to make this any kind of challenge.

WHATAHOOT (74A)! And WHATAFEAT! To have found so many common phrases that contain our states minus a letter is an extraordinary accomplishment. Bravo, Zachary and John! My favorite was 21A, which gave me a good laugh out loud when I deciphered the meaning of the clue. So clever. I look forward to more puzzles from this team.
I found this puzzle at times too easy, at other times just plain annoying.

I appreciate the callback to the recent-ish Ebert puzzle. Sneaky little clue that I never would have gotten otherwise, but quite funny! Kudos to the constructors - as a high schooler I tried and failed to compose Times crosswords, and I‚Äôm always impressed by those with the gift.

M I S P L A C E D indeed!

This one was a workout, even though I got the theme early and made use of it. Many of the clues just didn't click with me today. Not sure why that was, but I still got this solved without help. Took almost 45 minutes though.

PADAWAN and DURAG with a U were new to me. Clue for the former could have been "Thai specialty" and I would have entered the same thing. (Just quantifying my cluelessness here.)
very enjoyable original.  Entire east side was very easy north west corner nearly did me in southwest corner also very difficult. Thank you.

I actually forgot to look for the theme after completing the puzzle, which was tougher than usual, given that actors, movies, TV series, sports slang, etc. , are Not In My Wheelhouse.  
I definitely admire Zachary and honor John's contribution and collaboration.

The inevitable But:
      Then there was DURAG (which I was forced to alter/enter against my will) because it's DO, as in HairDO.  
The other painful entry was OAHUAN....which is just awful, no matter what certain argumentative folk might say.  When we lived there, it was clear that ehtnic/cultural identity mattered; island of origin did NOT.   (We Haoles were in the minority, which was interestingly instructive.)  

Okay, I'm still behind on Christmas missives, which I will then submit to the tender mercies of the USPS.  (Last year we got one card, postmarked Dec 11, in February...)  
Good day and good luck!
Eight minutes over my average time, which is how long it took me to replace ‚Äúreminds‚Äù with ‚Äúrewinds‚Äù, because I quit trying to keep up with the Star Wars franchise years ago.
Was fun guessing the US states and their encompassing answers with a  minimum of crosses.  However, a MISPLACED effort at the end to TRY to make sense of OOYDAUSAV.  Good fun all around.  Thanks.

I got the theme early with DEN [VER M(I)NT], but it didn't help (much) with the subsequent solve.
This usually "irks" me, but didn't today, because the hidden states were done so cleverly.  It's amazing to think how many words and phrases can be ALTERED by just changing one letter.

I think ALTERED STATES or MIS-PLACED would have made a better title for this puzzle than "Change Locations".
Does that count as a nit?

So, I judge, "Well done, indeed".  I don't think it's necessary to comment on the constructors' ages.  A puzzle is good, or it isn't.

Tough one for me - a really long workout and must confess that I wasn't catching on to the theme at all while I was solving. Had to stop and review after I was finished. No big deal. And... puzzle find today. A Thursday from October 20, 2016 by Alan Arbesfeld. Theme clues and answers: "Supposedly, some Australian birds can participate in the America's Cup," palindromically : EMUSSAILIASSUME "Peter the Great, Mother Teresa and Bob Marley, palindromically" ATSARANUNARASTA "My concealment of that footwear was so unfortunate," palindromically" TOOBADIHIDABOOT "That tropical entry could not have captured first place in the fruit competition, palindromically" NOWAYAPAPAYAWON Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=10/20/2016&g=47&d=A ....
Sorry but this Sunday seemed harder than the Saturday! T'was interesting, but it was also difficult.

My enthusiasm for this puzzle was not MISPLACED.

And somehow, it never occurred to me that there were no big cats in Australia. Duh, that whole continental drift thing. Of course, crocodiles are a much older species, and made the leap. No idea how or when the DINGO arrived there. I have a feeling I'm going on a deep dive into Aussie biology today, especially with five inches of snow outside.

From out in leftfield:

Did we ever get the answer to Friday's "Two truths and a lie" quiz?
Great Sunday puzzle. I must admit to having cheated -- not by two timing, but, rather, but asking Siri to help with the urban safety hazard.  That's what I get for writing MOONLANDER.  LOL
I liked the theme but I‚Äôm not a big fan of name trivia especially clustered together like today. Nothing to puzzle out - you either know or don‚Äôt.
My misspelling of Spearmen as Speermen added about 15 minutes to my time until I found it :). Great puzzle, though!
Spent way too much time (10 minutes) chasing possible rebus fill methods instead of correcting the tipo tapa TYPO in 79D.  Overthinking as per usual! Thanks!
OOHIMSOSCARED and its clue are just Best In Class! Good job you guys üëç

After you solve 32 down and discover the word that Roger Ebert used 32 times in his review of ‚ÄúNorth‚Äù, I highly recommend seeking it out on Metacritic and giving it a read. So passionate and entertaining. Miss that guy.

For me this Sunday puzzle solved like an excellent themeless puzzle. There were enough tough clues ‚Äî mixed with many extremely straightforward ones ‚Äî that I had two seas of white space to fill in towards the end.

I tried to grok the theme on the fly but it was just easier to keep solving more clues, having had no clue about the ALTERED STATES while solving. After finishing, I wanted to understand the shaded and circled squares.

What I am left scratching my head about is this: Where did the "misplaced" letters go? And is there some pattern to OOYDAUSAV that I'm missing?
A challenging and fun puzzle. LSU/LURK/MIKA was almost a natick for me, but I was able to surmise LURK.
DID SOME SCHOOL REPORTING? Perfect!! Spent some time trying to rebus STATIC for INDICATION OF BAD SERVICE. Fun, multi-pass puzzle. Theme was ok.

Some interesting clues, but the theme was lost on me until I read the column.

Amazing construction, however, considering the tender age of one the constructors.
Fun Sunday, thanks !
At some point soon we‚Äôre going to need new clues for 28-Across and 67-Across, no?
Blazed through this one for a new Sunday personal best of 12:29!
My brain must be mush today- I couldn't pick up on the theme at all, which made it a bit of a slog to see through to the end. Very clever though, and congrats on the young constructer's debut!

Off the topic of today's puzzle, but I have encountered the most fiendish, clever, and possibly unfair puzzle I've ever played.

It is January 8, 2015, and even after getting the revealer, I was stumped.

Congrats on a lovely debut, Zachary! I'm looking forward to more from you. 
When my son was about 4, he went to the driving range with his dad, and when his dad hit the ball my son said, very seriously, "You have done well, young Padawan." üòÇ  
Despite that answer being a gimme for me, its spelling was not, and I was flyspecking for probably 10 minutes before deciding to change PADoWAN/AVo to PADAWAN/AVA. ü§¶üèº‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

I thought the theme was excellent, and it helped me with a few of the fills. Well done!
Rollicking, rip-roaring fun!!!!!

Wanting to know more about 42-across, I found a funny bit (Wiki) trivia:

‚Äú[42 across] was nicknamed ‚Äòthe Pe[5],‚Äô allegedly due to his frequent fondling of himself, though this is disputed .. instead suggesting that [he] earned this nickname by being difficult to work with.‚Äù

 üòÇ

One of the biggest mistakes I make is comparing my time with others. Mind boggling times like 15 or less minutes to knock out this puzzle. On Sunday I‚Äôm quite pleased that I finish in under an hour. It‚Äôs a big puzzle and I type slow. So my question to the super solvers is this. What do you do with the rest of your day?

Wowsa -- congratulations, Zachary on an extraordinary debut at the ripe old age of 16!! Constructing, let alone completing, a Sunday puzzle is no small feat -- I hope we see many more from you! 

I especially enjoyed your constructor notes. Kudos to you for reaching out to John and, additional kudos to you, John, for spotting such  talent and agreeing to collaborate!

Happy Sunday, everyone!

Well, made this a lot harder on myself than need be--I got the general idea with DENVER M(I)NT, but figured there was some kind of two-directional rebus going on, one with the real state name, and one with the changed one; so I left all the circles blank until the end, then started filling them in with the [A/D] format until I realized -- D'uh! Also figured the circles would spell something out, then forgot to see what that something was. However, the real fun began when, prompted by @MOL's comment, I started investigating "do-rag" vs. "durag." Green's Dictionary of slang lists them both, as well as "doo-rag," and, frosty Elyria, Ohio, "dew rag." https://greensdictofslang.com/entry/4bg54fq But which was used more commonly? Well, according to Ngram Viewer, "durag" was by far the more common form from about 1800*-early 2000's, when "do-rag" spiked and surpassed it, then settled down, so that in 2025 the two forms are used about equally. *That is not a typo!: https://books.google.com/ngrams/graph?content=do-rag%2C+durag&year_start=1800&year_end=2022&corpus=en&smoothing=3 And do they do!

I do remember ALTEREDSTATES, and had the same reaction as @Caitlin Lovinger when filling it in....wow...weird movie. 
Spent a little time looking to see if each of the circled letters was supposed to be in another circle...as in needing to Change Locations. Did not get "MISPLACED" but at least went back to admire the trick after reading the column. 
16..holy cow...good job Zachary (and John)!
....well, at least it wasn't a rebus.

I'm interrupting my usual crossword commentary (Thanks for a nice Sunday workout, Z and J!) to pass along a bit of Xmas trivia. Last night, friends and I watched "The Man Who Invented Christmas"...a delightful movie about Charles Dickens and the writing of "A Christmas Carol." It inspired me to read about Dicken's life. There I discovered that when he wrote the novel "Barnaby Rudge", he included a talking raven, Grip, named after his own talking pet raven Grip. Edgar Allen Poe read the novel and it inspired him to write "The Raven."  I thought this crowd would enjoy the seasonal literary connection.

I thought this was a good puzzle overall.  

What follows, I hope, is constructive feedback.  

The revealer was unnecessary to the solve and served more as a redirection than an aid. I ignored the revealer as superfluous.

Much to my chagrin both ABEL/BASES and CAIN/ACIDS fit at 38-down and 41-across with no other letters filled in and I wasn‚Äôt sure of either pair! What a brilliant piece of construction if intended or a very fun coincidence if by accident
Wow, looking forward to the next 50+ years of crosswords from this constructor!
From cray to craw to crab ... I finally got there. Was a slog but had some amusing entries
I solved the puzzle. I do not understand the theme.

Rude awakening: It was ALI who said "It's hard to be humble when you're as great as I am" ?? I could have sworn it was Snoopy, right after he said "To know me is to love me." https://www.etsy.com/listing/1725999203/rare-collectible-1965-vintage-snoopy?ref=share_v4_lx Speaking of love, that was my experience with this puzzle. It was really a joyful ride. Kudos, Zachary! Getting published by the NYT at your age is no small feat, along with partnering with Mr. Kugelman, he of outstanding construction chops. Thank you both for this top-notch puzzle!
I came. I saw. I finally and grudgingly turned LAB into CLUB. üòú
There‚Äôs a typo in the answer key, 54a is incorrectly spelled ALE
Yes, PETEY is Mark‚Äôs best friend inside Lumon, but what does PETEY think of Mark? Mark is PETEY‚Äôs ‚Äúvery good friend‚Äù.  Classic lines among my trio of best/very-good friends.

This was the perfect Sunday puzzle for me today. After a day of brain work, I was very glad this pleasant diversion took longer than I usually spend. I enjoyed all of it, from the first moment when I saw the grid and thought, "Ooh! Layers!" until the last moment when I figured out what the revealer was all about.

It took a few trials and errors to figure how to deal with the circles. The first couple of things I tried did not help with the crosses, or worse, worked for some but not all. I tried to cram in philadelphiaMINT and gave up, then filled in DRUMcorpS but only some of the crosses were working--so maybe it was a rebus after all? So then I decided to leave those circles alone for awhile. Kind of like a beautiful snake you don't think is poisonous, but really, why risk it.

It took awhile to trust that the theme was not actually needed for the acrosses or the downs, and then it served the very pleasant function of just keeping me wondering about it until I looked back at the end.

And then reading the column and finding out one of the constructors is only 16! This in no way came across as an early effort. What a delicious outing.
I liked this one a lot and the revealer helped me as someone from another shore. The NW corner was particularly difficult. Well done!
It's probably been said but I don't feel like scrolling: isn't "Human" Australia's largest carnivore? Bigger than a dingo I'll say that much.
Why is it that all the tricky clues are ones that I have already solved? üòÑ

@Barry Ancona Yeah it seems a new Complaint has been unlocked! If a puzzle just looks like it MIGHT contain a rebus, this can now trigger a complaint. Constructors please note the following category of offense: Grid that looks like it might contain a rebus. To be safe, better avoid: Anything that could be considered a red herring.
Given that the crossword editors have taken to indicating with a circle where rebus squares exist, it was not unreasonable to wonder if today's puzzle had bi-directional rebuses.

@SP, it doesn‚Äôt work like that. You‚Äôre just replacing the letter that belongs there‚Äîthe O at the end of OHIO, for example‚Äîwith another letter: OHIM. The state has been altered, per the revealer at 110A.

OK here are my Sunday noms. I narrowed it down to my top 5 but added 4 more honorable mentions that I thought were also worthy.

5/25 Dylan Schiff ‚ÄúTravel Bug‚Äù
I‚Äôm sure some solvers were annoyed by this theme (WORMHOLES) and don‚Äôt like having to jump around the grid, but it is so multilayered (words associated with ‚Äúworm‚Äù, rebuses, long entries starting in one part of the grid and continuing to another) and was so impeccably constructed, astonishing, and fun it‚Äôs impossible not to include it. High on my list.
7/6 Zhou Zhang and Kevin Curry ‚ÄúEscape Room‚Äù A polarizing puzzle, for sure, but, in my opinion, a BREAKOUT performance by two of my favorite constructors. Very unique and full of Easter eggs. Reminds me of the lyric from [title of show]: ‚ÄúI‚Äôd rather be nine people‚Äôs favorite thing than 100 people‚Äôs ninth favorite thing.‚Äù This is one of my favorite things.
8/3 Jeremy Newton ‚ÄúHeavenly Voices‚Äù
This ‚ÄúStar Trek‚Äù themed puzzle was a crowd pleaser and probably a top contender. I can‚Äôt argue it was out of this world with an astonishing number of themed elements that were entertaining for everyone in one way or another.
9/14 Daniel Grinberg ‚ÄúBird‚Äôs Eye View‚Äù
Arguments on the true transliteration of the Roadrunner‚Äôs warning aside, this was a fresh, eye-catching, loving tribute that can‚Äôt be ignored. Brought a smile to everyone‚Äôs face.

@john ezra

(Continued‚Ä¶)

11/23 Trenton Charlston ‚ÄúSecond in Command‚Äù
I said at the time this was a POY contender and I stand by that. Not the flashiest theme (some punny entries where the first and second letters were transposed) but the themes were long and elegant, fresh, and the puzzle was also noteworthy for tremendous accessory fill and clever clues. As a constructor it impressed me tremendously.

Honorable mention
3/2 Adam Wagner ‚ÄúRainbow Connection‚Äù
Colorful theme (in more ways than one), fun to figure out and solve, with a high level of difficulty but smooth fill.
3/23 Alan Colin Kirk ‚ÄúWhere‚Äôd You Go?‚Äù
I‚Äôm always a sucker for punny themes and revealers. This one (ITSNOTYOUITSME with the letter U replaced by ME) was fresh, funny, and exciting, with some amazing themed entries.
9/28 Rich Katz ‚ÄúCentral Perk‚Äù
This tribute to ‚ÄúFriends‚Äù owed a lot to the Crossword gods for its symmetry and perfect title, but give Rich Katz his due for its conception and elegant construction. Even non-viewers of ‚ÄúFriends‚Äù enjoyed it.
11/2 Raphael Musa ‚ÄúOpen Faced‚Äù
Ok, not going to win any awards just because so many people abhor themeless Sundays, but constructing the Sunday grid with the lowest word count in history has got to be at least worth an honorable mention. Personally I had a blast with it.

@Jane Wheelaghan

I sympathize with the dislike of proper names or trivia, but I had the converse experience with which were difficult.* I share the sense that they trip up the experience, though.

I suspect some number of these answers must be permitted lest constructing the puzzles become impossible. Could an extension to the Tricky Clues section pick up more of the slack here, perhaps?

Perhaps a Tricky Answers list, no extra explanation or commentary needed; just an additional list of the proper nouns, obscure jargon, or crossword-ese that appears in the puzzle, without even noting which clues they answer?

*(I got MIKA, PADAWAN, and part of NEWELL. Newell and Mika regularly show up in certain verticals - technology and political media, respectively. Oddly, I apparently recognize Gabe by first name and not full last name. PADAWAN is a title (albeit fictional) and not a name, so it gets a fresh injection into culture with every new Star Wars media release. YENTE has come up before as crossword-ese.)

The Times Crossword from day one has always had plenty of proper nouns. The puzzle editors presumably thought readers of the newspaper should know things as well as words. Today's Times readers (or consumers of equivalent media) should be fine (with a cross or two to fill gaps in their knowledge base).

@Barry Ancona Part of my point is that there's no such "equivalent media" now. The Times used to be "of record" and could claim to be the closest thing to a central public square (as they often did for their opinion section). There is no such platform today.

"Perhaps a Tricky Answers list, no extra explanation or commentary needed; just an additional list of the proper nouns, obscure jargon, or crossword-ese that appears in the puzzle, without even noting which clues they answer?"

Before the internet, we used a physical dictionary, thesaurus, encyclopedia, atlas, etc., to look up words and things we didn't know. I hear they are all available online now.

@Jane Wheelaghan

2 years into solving, guessing the names has become part of the fun for me. On particularly difficult puzzles they become the cheat code in - look up the names first. Plus the inevitable dive down lots of  wikipedia rabbit holes. All fun.

The expression is "Out in left field."

@Barry Ancona
I looked this up and I know it comes from baseball, but why is the left field so much further away than the field on the right?

Jane,
It usually isn't. The origin of the phrase has been attributed to several specific ball fields, going back more than a century. Look for more online, or wait for a baseball history maven to provide some links.

@Jane Wheelaghan

I didn‚Äôt know why it was specifically left field and not right field, so I did some looking. 

The most logical explanation I could find, which is still not definitive, is that a runner rounding third base on the way home to score has the left fielder behind him, the right fielder to his left, and the center fielder somewhere between the two. 

So that runner would see a throw coming home to get him out from the right fielder and maybe the center fielder, but not from the left fielder. 

On the other hand, the team at bat has a coach at third base, so a runner heading around third would have that coach, who can see the play clearly, tell him whether to try to score or to stay at third. 

Interestingly, the phrase was first used in the music industry, to refer to a hit that seemingly came out of nowhere. People understood the baseball analogy.
Steve, I'm surprised you didn't know this one: https://etymology.kenliss.com/blog/out-in-left-field/

@Dan Collins

I solved this in less than 15 minutes late yesterday afternoon. (I'm not trying to brag, but I posted my actual time when I wrote my Diary of a Crossword Fiend review.) I don't consider myself a super solver; I'd reserve that for someone who can knock out a puzzle like this in seven or eight minutes.

Having all of Sunday free, I've written some summaries of the best NYT crossword puzzles for the upcoming Griddies awards and gone for a 13 mile bike ride. 

I don't know how long you've been solving these puzzles, but if your goal is to get faster at them, note that practice really does help. My Sunday average has dropped five minutes in the last six years, and it's rare that I take that long with a Sunday puzzle anymore.
